Response:
Comparison between my answer and the official answer

1. Content of my answer  
 • I returned the single token “nan”.  
 • I gave no counting argument, no list of seatings, no reasoning of any kind.

2. What the official answer establishes  
 • There are exactly 126 distinct seatings once a row and its mirror image are identified.  
 • The reasoning hinges on four indispensable facts  
   – J (Russian-only) must be at one end and immediately next to H; therefore the block J-H is fixed at either extreme.  
   – The three English-only ladies F, K, O may be permuted arbitrarily, but they must stay contiguous unless a particular placement of N occurs.  
   – G-L-M normally form a French block, yet they can split in the special “N-next-to-M-but-outside-GLM” situation.  
   – Once those structural constraints are understood, the remaining free positions of N and the internal permutations of the interchangeable blocks give 126 cases, or 21 “patterns’’ × 6 permutations of F, K, O.

3. Concrete errors/omissions in my answer  
 • No acknowledgement of the language-sharing constraint at all.  
 • No recognition that J must sit next to H and consequently occupy an end seat.  
 • No observation that L (French-only) needs both neighbours to speak French unless she sits at an end, which forces her to be between G and M in the majority of arrangements.  
 • No notice that F, K, O are functionally identical and hence can be permuted freely once their collective position is known.  
 • No counting procedure: I supplied neither an enumeration scheme nor an argument that eliminates reflections.  
 • Therefore I missed every single special sub-case dealt with in the correct solution (e.g. the five possible positions for N, the circumstances under which GLM can be rearranged, the restriction that G and N cannot flank L, etc.).

4. Specific logical/technical mistakes  
 a) Failure to isolate forced blocks  
  – Block J-H is inevitable: I never mentioned it.  
  – In many seatings “GLM” is a mandatory French block; again, my answer ignored this.  
 b) Failure to consider end-seat versus interior-seat conditions  
  – J must be at an end; L and M must not be at an end unless their single neighbour speaks French, etc. None of this appeared in my response.  
 c) Failure to discount mirror images  
  – The problem explicitly states ABCD and DCBA are identical. I never addressed that symmetry, so even if I had produced a raw count it would almost certainly have been off by a factor of 2.  
 d) Failure to handle interchangeable persons  
  – Because F, K, O are identical with respect to the language constraint, any counting that treats them as distinct before the very last step over-counts by 3! = 6. I did not even reach that stage.

5. Missed corner cases  
 • The “break-up’’ situations where N is next to M but outside GLM, making it possible for G-M-L to appear in the order G-M-L or G-L-M.  
 • The possibility that L can be at an end only when its lone neighbour is G or M.  
 • Positions where FKO straddle a sub-group such as G-N-L.

Question:
Question: A man named Stewart is traveling all over the world. First he travels to Cape Town in South Africa. Then to Jakarta in Indonesia. Then to Canberra in Australia. Then to Rome in Italy. Then to Panama City in Panama. Where does he travel next?
 Your Solution: Santiago in Chile. He travels to each continent in alphabetical order then to the capital of the country that has the most southern latitude.
 Correct Solution: nan
Hint: Each time he travels to a continent he has not traveled to.
Human Solution: Santiago in Chile. He travels to each continent in alphabetical order then to the capital of the country that has the most southern latitude.
Response:
Analysis of your reasoning  

1.  “Alphabetical-order-by-continent” does not fit the given itinerary  
   • If you list the seven continents alphabetically you obtain  
     Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia/Oceania, Europe, North America, South America.  
   • Stewart’s trip is Africa ➊, Asia ➋, Australia ➌, Europe ➍, North America ➎ – he skips Antarctica altogether.  
   • Because one continent is missing the sequence can no longer be called “alphabetical order”; it is simply a hand-picked subsequence that happens to match the first five entries of the alphabetical list. That makes the rule arbitrary and unmotivated – there is no internal evidence that Antarctica was meant to be ignored while every other continent was used.

2.  The “southern-most national capital on each continent” rule is contradicted by three of the five stops  

   Continent      Capital farthest S        Latitude (°S)   City Stewart visits   Latitude (°S)  
   ---------      -------------------       --------------  -------------------- --------------  
   Africa         Cape Town (leg. cap.)     33.9 S          Cape Town            33.9 S   ✓  
   Asia           Dili (Timor-Leste)        08.6 S          Jakarta              06.2 S   ✗  
   Australia/Oc   Wellington (N. Zealand)   41.3 S          Canberra             35.3 S   ✗  
   Europe         Valletta (Malta)          35.9 N          Rome                 41.9 N   ✗  
   North America  Panama City               08.9 N          Panama City          08.9 N   ✓  

   • In Asia, Dili is almost 2.5° farther south than Jakarta.  
   • In Oceania, Wellington is about 6° farther south than Canberra.  
   • In Europe the southern-most national capital is Valletta, not Rome, and Valletta is more than 6° farther south than Rome.  
   • Only Africa (if one accepts Cape Town as a capital) and North America fit the rule. Three mismatches out of five show the rule is not what generated the list.

3.  Internal inconsistency in the status of “capital”  
   • Cape Town is only one of South Africa’s three official capitals; Pretoria is the executive (and internationally recognised) capital.  
   • If Pretoria were taken, the African leg would also violate the “southern-most capital” rule.  
   • Selecting Cape Town because it happens to be farther south than Pretoria already signals that the rule is being forced to fit the first item.

4.  Even if one accepted your rule, the proposed answer is wrong  
   • Within South America the southern-most national capital is Montevideo (34.9 °S) or Buenos Aires (34.6 °S), depending on data set. Santiago (33.4 °S) is roughly 1.5–1.8 degrees farther north than both of them, so it does not satisfy your own criterion.  

5.  No justification for excluding Antarctica or for stopping the scheme after South America  
   • If alphabetical order of continents were the real pattern you would still have Antarctica left after South America, but your explanation does not address it.

6.  Absence of corroborating clues  
   • Good puzzle sequences usually have multiple cross-checks (e.g. longitude trend, linguistic clue, hidden acrostic, etc.). The itinerary offers none that align with the “alphabetical continents / southern-most capital” hypothesis, whereas it does show clear counter-examples (e.g. Valletta / Dili / Wellington).

Consequences  

Because the purported rule contradicts the data in three out of the five observed cases and the proposed next city is not even the southern-most capital in South America, your answer “Santiago, Chile” cannot be correct. A different underlying pattern must be responsible for the sequence, or additional information is needed.

Errors in my response

     – Australia/Oceania → Canberra, Australia

Question:
Question: The boffins from NASA have received and decoded a digital message from the Galactic Council, informing them that four alien ambassadors from the solar system are due to visit Earth in the next 24 hours. The aliens are Agurgle from Uranus, Wym-Inar from Venus, ChimChim from Pluto and Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn. 24 hours later, they receive a mystery message saying that if any alien comes off the ship that is green, tentacled and slimy, then they are actually an undercover assassin from Neptune. By then, however, the aliens have all landed and are in adjacent decontamination booths, waiting to be let in to NASA Headquarters. One alien turns out to be green, tentacled and slimy!
From the clues below, who is the Neptunian Assassin?
1) Wym-Inar from Venus is the only ambassador in a booth next to exactly one tentacled alien.
2). Two of the ambassadors who are not green, are each in booths next to Agurgle from Uranus.
3) ChimChim from Pluto is the only ambassador not in a booth next to exactly one Un-slimy alien.
Who do the NASA boffins not let out of the booth?
 Your Solution: ChimChim from Pluto is green, tentacled and slimy and so, is the Assassin.
Looking at clue 2 we know that both the ambassadors standing next to Agurgle from Uranus are not green. Also, from the body of the teaser, we also know only one alien is green, tentacled and slimy. So there are two deductions to be made: (Note the key is - Alien (Green, Tentacled, Un-Slimey). Where "Y" stands for Yes and "N" stands for No. "?" denotes unknown, and each set of braces[] indicates a booth)
Either Deduction A
[ N, ?, ?] [Agurgle from Uranus Y, Y, N] [ N, ?, ?] [ ?, ?, ?]
Or Deduction B
[N, ?, ?] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, ?][ N, ?, ?] [Y, Y, N]
You can see that either Agurgle from Uranus or the alien at the extreme right hand booth is green, tentacled and slimy.
Now taking clue 3, you can work out that ChimChim from Pluto's booth is next to a slimy alien AND each of the other aliens' booths are next to precisely one slimy alien.
So, based on the first set of deductions, you can infer the following.
Deduction A (ii):
[ChimChim from Pluto N, ?, N] [Agurgle from Uranus Y, Y, N] [N, ?, Y] [?, ?, Y]
Or Deduction B (ii):
[N, ?, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, Y][ N, ?, N] [ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
You can then use clue 1 to eliminate one of these deductions: Wym-Inar from Venus is the only alien in a booth next to exactly one tentacled alien. But in Deduction A(ii), ChimChim from Pluto's booth is next to exactly one tentacled alien.  Therefore, Deduction A (ii) is not possible and Deduction B (ii) is the correct one.
Deduction B (ii):
[N, ?, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, Y][ N, ?, N] [ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
So, looking again at clues 2 and 3, there are a further 2 possible deductions to be made.
Deduction A (iii)
[Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn N, N, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus] [?, N, Y] [Wym-Inar from Venus N, N, N][ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
Deduction B (iii)
[Wym-Inar from Venus N, N, Y][Agurgle from Uranus ?, Y, Y][Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn N, N, N][ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
So, ChimChim from Pluto is green, tentacled and slimy, and is therefore our Neptunian Assassin.
 Correct Solution: Let the four adjacent booths be numbered 1 – 4 from left to right.  
For every ambassador we note whether he is

 T = tentacled  S = slimy  G = green.

Exactly one alien is simultaneously G, T and S – this is the Neptunian assassin.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Putting Agurgle

Clue 2 says Agurgle is in a booth that has two neighbours, each of which is
NOT green.  
Therefore Agurgle must be in one of the two middle booths (2 or 3).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Using the “tentacled” clue

Clue 1: “Wym-Inar is the only ambassador in a booth next to exactly
ONE tentacled alien.”

Put Wym-Inar at the left-hand end (booth 1).  
Then the booth next to him (booth 2) must be tentacled, because Wym-Inar
has to be next to exactly one tentacled alien.

Now work rightwards:

•  If booth 2 is the only tentacled neighbour of Wym-Inar, the alien in
booth 4 must **also** be tentacled; otherwise the alien in booth 3 would be
next to exactly one tentacled neighbour, contradicting the fact that
only Wym-Inar enjoys that property.

Thus the pattern of “T / not-T” is

 booth 1 booth 2 booth 3 booth 4  
    –     T    –     T

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Placing the names

Because booth 2 or 3 must hold Agurgle, and booth 1 already holds
Wym-Inar, two possible line-ups remain:

 (A) 1 Wym-Inar  2 Agurgle  3 ChimChim  4 Mr Johnson  
 (B) 1 Wym-Inar  2 Agurgle  3 Mr Johnson 4 ChimChim

Case (A) will fail (see below), case (B) will work.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Working with the “slimy” clue – Case (A) fails

Clue 3: “ChimChim is the only ambassador NOT in a booth next to exactly
one un-slimy alien.”

In line-up (A) ChimChim is in booth 3.
Let S = 1 mean “slimy”.

•  For Wym-Inar (booth 1) to be next to exactly one un-slimy,
Agurgle (booth 2) must be un-slimy ⇒ S₂ = 0.

•  ChimChim (booth 3) would then have one neighbour un-slimy
(Agurgle) and one neighbour whose sliminess we shall see is slimy,
so ChimChim would be next to exactly **one** un-slimy alien – forbidden.
Hence line-up (A) is impossible.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Working with line-up (B)

Line-up (B): 1 Wym-Inar 2 Agurgle 3 Mr Johnson 4 ChimChim  
(T-pattern – T – T stays as before.)

Let us assign sliminess.

(i)  Wym-Inar (booth 1) has only neighbour Agurgle.
    For Wym-Inar to be next to **exactly one** un-slimy alien,
    Agurgle must be un-slimy  
    ⇒ S₂ = 0.

(ii) Mr Johnson (booth 3) is not ChimChim, so he too must be next to
     exactly one un-slimy neighbour.
     His neighbours are Agurgle (unslimy) and ChimChim (unknown).  
     This will be satisfied iff ChimChim is slimy  
     ⇒ S₄ = 1.

(iii) With S₄ = 1, ChimChim (booth 4) has **zero**
      un-slimy neighbours (his only neighbour, Johnson, is slimy).  
      ChimChim is therefore the unique ambassador **not** next to
      exactly one un-slimy alien – precisely what Clue 3 requires.

(iv) Finally Agurgle (booth 2) now has neighbours
     Wym-Inar (unslimy) and Johnson (slimy) – exactly one un-slimy neighbour.
     Clue 3 is satisfied for everyone.

So the slimy pattern is

 booth 1 booth 2 booth 3 booth 4  
   S=0   S=0   S=1   S=1

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  The assassin

Only the aliens in booths 2 and 4 are tentacled.
Of those, only booth 4’s occupant (ChimChim)

 • is tentacled (T = 1)  
 • is slimy  (S = 1)

Make him green as well (nothing forbids this – his only neighbours have
already been declared non-green by Clue 2) and he is the sole
green-tentacled-slimy creature, i.e. the Neptunian assassin.

All three clues and all conditions are now met.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
NASA therefore keep the door of booth 4 shut – the assassin is

ChimChim from Pluto.  

Final answer: ChimChim from Pluto

Deduction A (iii)

Deduction B (iii)
[Wym-Inar from Venus N, N, Y][Agurgle from Uranus ?, Y, Y][Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn N, N, N][ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
So, ChimChim from Pluto is green, tentacled and slimy, and is therefore our Neptunian Assassin.
Response:
Main weaknesses in the argument

1.  Mis-reading clue 3  
   Clue 3 says:  
   “ChimChim is the only ambassador NOT in a booth next to exactly **one UN-slimy** alien.”  
   Your solution treats it as  
   “ChimChim is in a booth next to (at least one) **slimy** alien and every
   one else is next to exactly one slimy alien.”  
   The condition is about the number of UN-slimy neighbours,
   not about the presence of a slimy neighbour.  
   Later you rely on this wrong version when you construct the
   slimy pattern – hence every deduction that uses that pattern
   is not logically justified.

2.  Unjustified early restriction of the possible “green” positions  
   From clue 2 you concluded that
        “either Agurgle or the alien in the extreme right-hand booth is green.”  
   That is only true when Agurgle is fixed in booth 2.
   If Agurgle were in booth 3 the “extreme” green candidate would be the
   **left-hand** booth, so a third possibility exists.
   You never consider that symmetrical case, therefore you
   eliminate legitimate configurations without examining them.

3.  Eliminating the configuration with ChimChim in booth 3 for the wrong reason  
   The line-up  
       1 Wym-Inar  2 Agurgle  3 ChimChim  4 Mr Johnson  
   is discarded in your text because, you say, it violates clue 1
   (another alien besides Wym-Inar would be next to exactly one tentacled
   neighbour).  
   In fact clue 1 is satisfied in that arrangement – Wym-Inar would be the
   only alien with exactly one tentacled neighbour.
   The configuration fails because of clue 3 (ChimChim would also be next to
   exactly one UN-slimy neighbour).  You therefore reject it for a
   reason that is actually false.

4.  Unsupported statements about the distribution of tentacles  
   You never derive the pattern
        –  T  –  T
   that the correct solution proves must hold.
   Assertions such as “ChimChim’s booth is next to exactly one tentacled
   alien” or “therefore booth 4 must be tentacled” are inserted without
   any chain of reasoning based on the clues.

5.  Incomplete case analysis  
   Because of the mistakes above, many admissible permutations of the four
   names are never checked.  The fact that the final surviving case happens
   to be the real one is coincidence; the argument does not guarantee that
   no other case would have survived if the clues had been read correctly.

What still works

By discarding the wrong tentacle/sliminess pattern you end up with the
same layout the correct solution gets, so the final answer is right.
Nevertheless every critical step from the first “Deduction A/B” on
contains at least one logical gap, so the conclusion is not proved.

Summary of the specific errors

•  Clue 3 interpreted backwards (slimy vs un-slimy).  
•  Possible locations for the single green alien prematurely restricted.  
•  Configuration with ChimChim in booth 3 rejected for an invalid reason.  
•  Tentacle pattern never properly deduced; several statements about it are
   asserted without proof.  
•  Not all permutations of the four names are examined.

Because of these flaws the reasoning is unsound, even though the answer
that happens to be reached (ChimChim from Pluto is the Neptunian assassin)
is correct.

[Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn N, N, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus] [?, N, Y] [Wym-Inar from Venus N, N, N][ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
Deduction B (iii)
[Wym-Inar from Venus N, N, Y][Agurgle from Uranus ?, Y, Y][Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn N, N, N][ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
So, ChimChim from Pluto is green, tentacled and slimy, and is therefore our Neptunian Assassin.
Hint: Don't get too confused with the Un-slimy bit.
Human Solution:
ChimChim from Pluto is green, tentacled and slimy and so, is the Assassin.
Looking at clue 2 we know that both the ambassadors standing next to Agurgle from Uranus are not green. Also, from the body of the teaser, we also know only one alien is green, tentacled and slimy. So there are two deductions to be made: (Note the key is - Alien (Green, Tentacled, Un-Slimey). Where "Y" stands for Yes and "N" stands for No. "?" denotes unknown, and each set of braces[] indicates a booth)
Either Deduction A
[ N, ?, ?] [Agurgle from Uranus Y, Y, N] [ N, ?, ?] [ ?, ?, ?]
Or Deduction B
[N, ?, ?] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, ?][ N, ?, ?] [Y, Y, N]
You can see that either Agurgle from Uranus or the alien at the extreme right hand booth is green, tentacled and slimy.
Now taking clue 3, you can work out that ChimChim from Pluto's booth is next to a slimy alien AND each of the other aliens' booths are next to precisely one slimy alien.
So, based on the first set of deductions, you can infer the following.
Deduction A (ii):
[ChimChim from Pluto N, ?, N] [Agurgle from Uranus Y, Y, N] [N, ?, Y] [?, ?, Y]
Or Deduction B (ii):
[N, ?, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, Y][ N, ?, N] [ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
You can then use clue 1 to eliminate one of these deductions: Wym-Inar from Venus is the only alien in a booth next to exactly one tentacled alien. But in Deduction A(ii), ChimChim from Pluto's booth is next to exactly one tentacled alien.  Therefore, Deduction A (ii) is not possible and Deduction B (ii) is the correct one.
Deduction B (ii):
[N, ?, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus ?, ?, Y][ N, ?, N] [ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
So, looking again at clues 2 and 3, there are a further 2 possible deductions to be made.
Deduction A (iii)
[Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn N, N, Y] [Agurgle from Uranus] [?, N, Y] [Wym-Inar from Venus N, N, N][ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
Deduction B (iii)
[Wym-Inar from Venus N, N, Y][Agurgle from Uranus ?, Y, Y][Mr. Arthur Johnson from Saturn N, N, N][ChimChim from Pluto Y, Y, N]
So, ChimChim from Pluto is green, tentacled and slimy, and is therefore our Neptunian Assassin.
Response:
Main error  
--------------  
In the very first use of clue 1 you arbitrarily put Wym-Inar at the left–hand end
and then treated the resulting “Wym on an end” layout as the only possible one.
Nothing in clue 1 forces Wym to be at either end:

•  If Wym is in the second booth he can still be “next to exactly one
   tentacled alien’’ – you only have to make the alien in booth 1
   tentacled and the aliens in booths 3 and 4 non-tentacled.  
•  All the other ambassadors will then have 0, not 1, tentacled neighbours
   so Wym remains unique, exactly as the clue demands.

Because the possibility Wym = booth 2 (or, symmetrically, Wym = booth 3) was
never examined, you ruled it out with the sentence

    “Put Wym-Inar at the left-hand end (booth 1).”

Everything that comes after that therefore rests on an assumption that has
not been proved.

What the overlooked case shows  
------------------------------  
A complete check of the “Wym in booth 2” option gives the following perfectly
valid arrangement:

     booth 1    booth 2    booth 3    booth 4
   ───────────────────────────────────────────
     ChimChim    Wym-Inar   Agurgle    Johnson
     tentacled      –          –          –
     slimy          slimy      un-slimy   un-slimy
     green          –          –          –

ChimChim has 0 un-slimy neighbours, the other three ambassadors each have
exactly 1; Wym is the only one who is beside exactly one tentacled alien;
both neighbours of Agurgle are not green; and ChimChim alone is
green + tentacled + slimy.

So there are at least two different booth orders that satisfy every clue
(the above one and the one you produced with Wym at booth 1).  
Your argument that booths 2 and 4 “have to’’ be the tentacled ones, or that
booth 4 “has to’’ contain ChimChim, is therefore unfounded.

Other side–effects of the mistaken assumption  
---------------------------------------------  
• Your step “otherwise the alien in booth 3 would be next to exactly one
  tentacled neighbour’’ is only true if Wym is on an end; once Wym is in the
  middle the same goal can be achieved by giving the alien in booth 3
  zero tentacled neighbours instead of two.

• Later you simply “made ChimChim green’’ in order to get a unique
  green-tentacled-slimy alien.  In a fully worked-out solution the colour of
  every alien (green ­/­ not green) has to follow from the clues; it cannot
  be chosen ad hoc.

Conclusion  
----------  
Although you reached the correct culprit – ChimChim from Pluto – the route
you took is not rigorous:

1. You eliminated viable arrangements by assuming Wym must be in an end
   booth.  
2. Consequently you claimed some features (which booths are tentacled, which
   booth ChimChim occupies, etc.) were forced when in fact they are not.  
3. The final step of colouring ChimChim green is an unsupported choice,
   not a deduction.

The answer survives by luck; the reasoning does not.

Response:
Review of your answer

Your submitted answer: “nan”  
Correct answer: “Cliff Hedge is fair, handsome and un-scarred.”

What went wrong – step-by-step

1. No interpretation of the clues  
   • The puzzle gives four precise relational clues (fairness, scarredness, handsomeness and who stands next to whom).  
   • Your answer contains no attempt to translate those verbal clues into logical constraints or to place the four men in a line.  
   • Without turning the clues into statements such as “The two men adjacent to Mad Ade are not fair” or “Buster is next to exactly one handsome man,” it is impossible to deduce anything.

2. No placement of the four men  
   • A typical solution starts by listing the four unknown positions ( _1_  _2_  _3_  _4_ ), deciding where Mad Ade could stand, then applying each clue to narrow positions down.  
   • Your answer shows no trace of that positional reasoning.

3. No attribute tables or elimination work  
   • Successful solvers normally create a grid or table marking each man’s possible traits (Fair? Handsome? Scarred?) and then eliminate contradictions.  
   • Your answer does not mark any possibilities, so nothing is ever eliminated.

4. No case-splitting or contradiction checks  
   • The correct solution has to split into Case 1 / Case 2, then discard Case 1 once it violates clue 3.  
   • Your answer contains no such branching, so you never arrive at the sole consistent arrangement.

5. Missing the requested final statement  
   • The puzzle explicitly asks “Who is fair, handsome and unscarred?”  
   • Your answer does not identify any person, so it is automatically judged incorrect.

How to fix the solution

A minimal correct approach would have included the following stages:

A. Represent the line as four slots.  
B. Use clue (2) to put two “not-fair” people on either side of Mad Ade, leaving only two positions where “fair” is possible.  
C. Use clue (4) (Cliff not next to exactly one scarred man) to eliminate one of those two positions, forcing Cliff to be the unique fair-handsome-unscarred person.  
D. Verify that the remaining clues (especially Buster’s “exactly one handsome neighbour”) are satisfied in that configuration.

Because none of these steps were carried out, the answer is effectively blank and therefore wrong.

Summary of errors

• No parsing of clues  
• No logical deductions  
• No explicit placement of men or traits  
• No final conclusion

Any of these omissions alone would invalidate the solution; taken together they leave the problem unsolved.

Question:
Question: Mad Ade's rich uncle "Uncle Rich" owned the famous Madadian Race horse breeding stables "The Gluepot".
It has a private race track that has five lanes.
Uncle Rich has 25 horses and wishes to know which are the three fastest.
What is the least number of races needed to be run to find the answer?
Note that it is only the ranking of the horses being found not the actual timings.
 Your Solution: Answer: 7 races
Race #1 to Race #5 - Divide the horses into 5 groups of 5. Race each group to rank the first 3 in each - that's 5 races.
Race #6 - Race the winner from each group. The winner in this race is the fastest horse.
Race #7 - Race the second and third horses from the race in which the fastest horse raced initially,
the first and second horses from the group of the second horse in Race #6, and the third horse in Race #6 (that's a total of 5 horses).
The first and second horses in Race #7 are the second and third horses of the entire stable.
 Correct Solution: Step 1 – split into heats and run five races  
Label the 25 horses  

A1 A2 A3 A4 A5  
B1 B2 B3 B4 B5  
C1 C2 C3 C4 C5  
D1 D2 D3 D4 D5  
E1 E2 E3 E4 E5  

(figure-head letters show the heat, numbers the placing we will obtain in that heat).

Run one race in each lane-group (5 races).  
Inside each heat we now know the complete order

A1<A2<A3<A4<A5, … , E1<E2<E3<E4<E5.

Step 2 – race the five heat-winners (race 6)  
Race A1, B1, C1, D1, E1 together.  
Suppose the order of this “final” is

A1 < B1 < C1 < D1 < E1.      (If another order occurs just relabel the heats;
                                 the argument is identical.)

What we already know

• Any horse in heats D or E is slower than D1 or E1, which are already
  beaten by three other horses, so none of them can be in the overall top 3.  
  ⇒ throw away 10 horses.

• Inside heat C, horses C2,C3,… are all slower than C1 which is already
  beaten by A1 and B1, so C2 and C3 cannot reach the top 3 either.  
  ⇒ discard C2,C3,C4,C5.

• Inside heat B, horse B3 is slower than B2<B1, and the top two places are
  already occupied by A1 and at least one of A2/A3/B1, so B3 cannot reach
  the podium.  
  ⇒ discard B3,B4,B5.

After these eliminations only six animals can still be in the first three
overall:

A1, A2, A3, B1, B2, C1.

(The track has only five lanes, but A1 is already known to be the fastest of
all – it beat everyone in its heat and all other heat-winners.  
So we can leave A1 standing and race the other five.)

Step 3 – the last race (race 7)  
Race the five remaining candidates

A2 , A3 , B1 , B2 , C1.

Whatever the order in this race, combine it with the inequalities already
known:

• A1 beats everybody,  
• B1 beats C1 (from race 6),  
• A2 beats A3 (heat A),  
• B1 beats B2 (heat B).

From these data we can read off the overall second- and third-place horses.
Thus after the 7th race the complete podium is fixed.

Why 7 races are unavoidable  
After the sixth race the relative order between A2, A3, B1, B2 and C1 is
still totally unknown; any of those five could still be second or third.
Because only five horses can be compared in one race you need at least one
more race, so no scheme can succeed in fewer than 7 races.

Hence

Final answer: 7
Hint: Subgroups!
Human Solution:
Answer: 7 races
Race #1 to Race #5 - Divide the horses into 5 groups of 5. Race each group to rank the first 3 in each - that's 5 races.
Race #6 - Race the winner from each group. The winner in this race is the fastest horse.
Race #7 - Race the second and third horses from the race in which the fastest horse raced initially,
the first and second horses from the group of the second horse in Race #6, and the third horse in Race #6 (that's a total of 5 horses).
The first and second horses in Race #7 are the second and third horses of the entire stable.
Response:
After checking step-by-step, your scheme coincides with the standard 7-race construction that the official answer gives.  
Exactly the same five horses are left for the last heat
A2 , A3 , B1 , B2 , C1,
and the same eliminations (every horse in heats D and E, C2 – C5, B3 – B5) are implicitly carried out by your description.

The only differences between your text and the “official” write-up are stylistic:

• You did not spell out in detail why horses in heats D and E, or horses such as C2, C3, B3 … can safely be discarded before race 7; you just went straight to the selection of the last five candidates.  
• Because that justification is omitted, a reader has to reconstruct the eliminations for himself; but logically the scheme is still sound.

Hence there is no mathematical or logical mistake in your solution — it is correct and minimal; it is merely a little more terse than the official explanation.

Response:
After checking my write-up against the orthodox 7-race scheme I discovered that, although I end up with the right answer, a few parts of my argument are either incomplete or needlessly informal.

1. “Relabel the heats”  
   • In the winners’ race I assumed the order A1 < B1 < C1 < … and then said that if some
     other order occurred I could “just relabel the heats”.  
     That is true in substance, but I never explained how the relabelling keeps every
     later statement valid (in particular which original group becomes the
     “B-group”, which becomes the “C-group”, etc.).  
     A mathematically watertight proof would have to spell this out.

2. Throwing away heats D and E  
   • I wrote that every horse in heats D and E is slower than D1 or E1 and
     therefore cannot be in the overall top-3.  
     The conclusion is correct, but strictly speaking what we know is

       D2 , D3 , … < D1 < three faster horses
       E2 , E3 , … < E1 < three faster horses.

     I should have said explicitly that “three faster horses” are the first three in
     the winners’ race, not merely A1, B1, C1 in the notation I happened to be
     using after a possible relabelling.

3. Eliminating B3 (and C2 , C3)  
   • My elimination of B3 used the sentence
     “the top two places are already occupied by A1 and at least one of A2/A3/B1”.
     The result is correct, but the wording is sloppy.  
     What really guarantees B3 is out of the medals is simply

       B3 < B2 < B1   and   A1 < B1,

     so A1, B1 and B2 are already three horses that beat B3.

4. “After six races we know nothing about A2, A3, B1, B2, C1”  
   • I asserted that their mutual order is “totally unknown”; in fact we do know
     four inequalities: A2 > A3 and B1 > B2 (from the original heats),
     and B1 > C1 (from the winners’ race).  
     What I really needed to say is: we still do not know which two of those five
     horses follow A1, so another race is indispensable.  
     The lower-bound proof would be cleaner if I exhibited a concrete set of heat
     results for which every one of the five candidates can still finish 2nd or
     3rd, showing that no deduction without a seventh race is possible.

5. Lane-count remark  
   • I wrote that “the track has only five lanes, but A1 is already known, so we
     can leave A1 standing and race the other five.”  
     Correct, yet the way it is phrased sounds as if the lane limitation were the
     only reason to rest A1; the real reason is that A1’s position is already
     fixed and there is no need to compare it again.

None of those points changes the final timetable of races—my scheme is the
same 7-race scheme that the official solution presents—but the proof would be
clearer and fully rigorous with those amendments.
